title-group.article-title: Modeling of one-dimensional thermal response of silica-phenolic composites with volume ablation

article-meta.aff: Center for Composite Materials and Structures, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Jun Liang, Center for Composite Materials and Structures, Key Laboratory of Science and Technology for National Defence, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150080, P. R. China. Email: liangj@hit.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The silica-phenolic composites experience volume ablation when exposed to a radiant heat flux. Based on the analysis of mechanisms during volume ablation, a mathematical model was developed to predict the one-dimensional thermal response of the ablative material in this paper. After discretizing the space and time domain, the governing equations were described using the implicit finite differential form. Both the heat-mass transfer process and the moving boundary caused by thermal expansion, as well as the variation of pore pressure due to concentration and flow of the decomposition gases were considered in the formulation of the model. The thermal response of silica-phenolic composites during the volume ablation, including temperature distribution, pore pressure distribution, volume fraction of the phase components and degree of decomposition, were calculated by the proposed model. The time-dependent temperature progressions at different material depths were measured using a solar radiation heating experiment platform. The experimental and calculated temperature profiles are in good agreement.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The volume ablation process of resin matrix composites, when the material mass decreases due to internal gas generation, is generally associated with complex thermal physico-chemical changes, heat-mass transfer processes and irreversible changes of thermomechanical and thermophysical properties.1 These dynamic processes are complex and coupled but also significant to the calculation of the temperature field and the thermal stress field of ablative materials. Therefore, it is necessary to recognize the volume ablation process for further research on the mechanical properties of thermoprotective materials in high temperature environment.

The ablative materials have some similar physicochemical changes in the volume ablation process.2–8 Henderson in 19859–13 established a mathematical model to simulate thermal response of glass-filled polymer composite. The model applied an nth order approximation for the rate of decomposition and the Darcy's law for defining diffusion of decomposition gases through the char structure. Additionally, the specific heat and thermal conductivity of virgin and char components, heat of decomposition and the kinetic parameters were experimentally determined and used as input data to the model. The model can well characterize the thermal behavior of polymer composite when the volume ablation occurs. Then, Sullivan et al. in 199214–16 regarded thermochemical decomposition and expansion of polymeric materials as a temperature-displacement-diffusion coupling problem and developed a finite element method to solve the fully-coupled problem. The variations of stress, strain in plane strain and plane stress state versus temperature of carbon/phenolic composites were presented. The similar model was introduced by Matsuura et al. in 2010.17,18 The numerical results of thermomechanical response of silica-phenolic ablator under high heating rates show good agreement with the data of three typical experiments, namely restrained thermal growth (RTG) tests, free thermal expansion (FTE) tests and laser heating tests. The sequential method was used by Mcmanus and Springer in 1992.19–22 The thermal response was firstly presented when carbon phenolic composite was rapidly heated to high temperature. Based on that, the mechanical response of the material was predicted. Dimitrienko23–25 has done many works in the mechanical behavior of composites under high temperature. In his works, two functions were defined to describe the attenuation of the temperature-dependent elastic and strength characteristics in volume ablation process. Recently, Bai et al. in 200826,27 developed a model to predict the thermal responses of fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) composites under elevated and high temperatures. The one-dimensional model used temperature-dependent thermophysical properties. The temperature profile, effective thermal conductivity and specific heat capacity were determined by the model when FRP composite was subjected to a given thermomechanical loading. However, only the heat transfer process was taken into account in their work. Gibson et al. in 201228 discussed the high temperature behavior and fire response of thermoplastic and thermosetting matrix composites under load in fire.

Actually, the pore pressure caused by the accumulation of the decomposition gases increases as the pyrolysis reaction proceed, which in turn induces the diffusion of decomposition gases through the porous solid skeleton. Therefore, the transient heat and mass transfer process due to decomposition gases flow will happen during the volume ablation. Also, the thermal expansion will also appear. The moving boundary becomes significant, since it will affect the thermal and mechanical behavior of materials in high temperature environments. However, the previous studies have not focused on it. Therefore, the effect of moving boundary must be considered in the formulation of thermal response model.

This study proposed a volume ablation model for silica-phenolic composite in high temperature environment. A modified first order Arrhenius equation was used to calculate the kinetics of decomposition of ablative materials. The temperature/diffusion coupled problem was discretized in time and space domains. The moving boundary and thermal blockade effect were considered in the model. A solar radiation heating experiment was carried out by using sunlight as the heat source. The calculated temperature profiles were compared with the measured values in the radiation heating experiments to evaluate the accuracy of the model.

sec.title: Mechanism analysis of silica-phenolic composite during volume ablation
sec.p: As a kind of resin matrix ablative composites, silica-phenolic composites have many advantages, such as simple preparing technique, short processing cycle, cheap cost, low thermal conductivity, good thermal stability, excellent thermal insulation property and good ablative performance. For this, they are widely used in the thermal protection systems of many vehicle and nozzles of the solid rocket motor.

The volume ablation of the resin matrix composite is mainly owing to the pyrolysis reaction. The silica-phenolic composites are composed of silica fiber (with SiO2 accounting for 98%), phenolic resin and little pore for the initial state. The delamination physical model during volume ablation process is shown in Figure 1. The external surface is the gas boundary layer. Prior to the onset of thermal decomposition, heat transfer in the material is a result of pure conduction. Only the minor thermal expansion appears in ablative material. When the material reaches sufficiently high temperature (200–300℃), the phenolic resin degrades to form carbonaceous char and gaseous products in an inert environment or in air.5,12,29 Initially, these decomposition gases are trapped due to the low porosity and permeability of the material in pyrolytic layer. For silica-phenolic composite, the porosity and permeability are sufficiently small to cause high internal pressure, which are, in turn, responsible for the large expansion of the solid matrix. In addition, carbon residue from the pyrolysis reaction and silica fiber reinforced phase of composites form porous char skeleton as shown in Figure 2. As the pyrolysis reactions proceed, the generation of decomposition gas is accelerated, and gas pressure in the pore increases rapidly. When the pore pressure becomes sufficiently high, the decomposition gases begin to flow through the char layer and filtrate out of the material surface.29,30 The injection of the decomposition gases into the gas boundary layer can increase the thickness of boundary layer and can block the aerodynamic heating. Furthermore, only gases near the external heating surface of materials have enough time to inject into the surroundings. Both the porosity and gas permeability are small in the depth of materials, where the pore pressure will reach a local peak with the accumulation of decomposition gases. This peak moves towards the insulation surface of materials with the heating time.29 No physical and chemical changes appear to the material below the pyrolytic layer. Figure 1.
Delamination physical model of silica-phenolic composites during volume ablation.
Figure 2.
The morphology of silica-phenolic composites after volume ablation.

sec.title: Problem description
sec.p:
The one-dimensional heat-mass transfer process is modeled for the silica-phenolic composite during volume ablation. The specimens of silica-phenolic composite measure 10 mm in length, 10 mm in width and 15 mm in depth. One surface of the specimen in the through-thickness direction is heated with a radiant heat flux, while the other surfaces of the specimen are insulated. The front surface and back surface in the through-thickness direction is applied 0.1 MPa pressure as boundary condition. The initial pressure and temperature of the specimen are 0.1 MPa and 12℃, respectively. The load and boundary conditions are illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Load and boundary condition of solving problem.

sec.title: Experiment
sec.p:
A solar radiation heating experiment platform was designed to measure the in-depth, time-dependent temperature profiles of composites exposed to a radiant heat flux. The temperature measurements are conducted to provide the experimental data necessary to evaluate the accuracy of the numerical model. The experimental platform consists of Fresnel lens (80 cm × 80 cm, focal length of 130 cm), prism (made of K9 glass) and thermocouples temperature measurement system, as shown in Figure 4. The prism is mounted vertically below the Fresnel lens, while the graphite fixture is mounted above the base plate, as shown in Figure 4(b) and (c). The specimen is shielded from the insulation by a ceramic tube which is placed in the hole of the graphite fixture, as shown in Figure 4(d). In addition, a thin sheet of aluminum is attached on the external graphite fixture to reflect the incident light on the graphite fixture as much as possible. The sunlight focused by Fresnel lens and prism is used as the light source. The time-dependent temperature of the material at different depths is measured by the thermocouple system. The apparatus can adjust the distance of the prism and the specimen to produce strong radiant heat fluxes. Figure 4.
Solar radiation heating experiment platform. (a) principle diagram, (b) experiment facility, (c) prism, (d) graphite fixture and (e) small-scale specimen.

In order to make the sunlight vertical incidence to the specimen surface, the apparatus should be adjusted before experiment. To prevent the specimen from heating during the adjustment process, an insulated plate with the specimen location mark was mounted vertically above the specimen. Firstly, the Fresnel lens was adjusted to focus on the sun. Subsequently, the position of the prism and specimen were adjusted with the mark on the insulated plate. Finally, the insulated plate was removed to start experiment. The temperature data and the overall rotation angle of the apparatus were recorded, and the heat flux in the experiment was estimated by the inverse heat transfer problem (IHTP).31 In order to estimate the heat flux in the experiment, a subsequent experiment must be conducted to provide the temperature data for the small-scale specimen (the size of 5 mm × 5 mm × 3 mm, as shown in Figure 4(e)). The subsequent experiment process was within 10 s to assure only heat conduction in the material, and the maximum temperature of the small-scale specimen was less than 100℃. Thus, three sets of temperature data were corresponding with the three rotation angle of the apparatus. The estimated heat fluxes of two specimens in the radiant heating experiment are illustrated in Figure 5. It is clear that the large change in the heat flux is evident when the apparatus rotates. Because the adjustment of rotation angle of the apparatus is completed within 2–4 s, the heat flux in that time is assumed to be linear. Figure 5.
Heat flux estimated by inverse heat transfer problem (IHTP) in solar radiation heating experimental process. (a) specimen 1 and (b) specimen 2.

The experiment platform can provide a high radiant heat flux in a short time. This rapid heating process is more similar with the true service environment of materials. However, the experiment platform is only in the preliminary design and testing stage, many devices still need to be improved further.

sec.title: One-dimensional thermal response
sec.p: When a radiant heat flux is applied to the silica-phenolic composites, the pyrolysis reaction of phenolic resin occurs as mentioned in section 2. The volume fraction of resin components and density of composite will be changed by the volume ablation. Also, the porosity and gas permeability of the material increase with the increase of temperature. The thermal and mass transport properties will change simultaneously. Additionally, the accumulation of the decomposition gases can cause the increase of pore pressure and further lead to moving boundary of materials.

sec.title: Discretization in space and time domains
sec.p: The analytical solution of partial differential equation of heat conduction is difficult to be obtained. Only the solution of the object with simple shape under some assumptions can be solved by the analytical method. The majority of problems can be solved by the numerical method. One approach to solving the present problem is to discretize the space and time domains through transformation into finite difference form and to solve the subsequent system of algebraic equations for the temperature field.

sec.title: Discretizing space domain
sec.p:
In order to convert the continuous problem into discontinuous problem in space domain, the specimen is meshed in the through-thickness direction. The mesh method is used as follows: the position of node is specified firstly. Then, the interface of the control volume is located in the center of two adjacent nodes. Furthermore, to obtain the temperature at boundary, both of the front surface and back surface has a node, respectively. The thickness of volume element at the front surface and back surface is Δδ/2, while others is Δδ. In this way, the slab is actually divided into M + 1 volume elements as shown in Figure 6. Assuming the uniform temperature in each volume element, the temperature of the volume element is equal to the node temperature. The schematic of space discretization is illustrated in Figure 7(a). The actual temperature curve, denoted by short dash line, is replaced by the approximation temperature curve, denoted by solid line, after space discretization. The temperature of real point is equal to that of each volume element. Thus, the continuous problem over space domain has been converted into the discontinuous problem with M + 1 spatial nodes. Figure 6.
Mesh of specimen for silica-phenolic composite in the thickness direction.
Figure 7.
Schematic of discretization in space and time domain of one-dimension thermal response model. (a) space domain and (b) time domain.

sec.title: Discretizing time domain
sec.p: Similarly, the computation time, t is divided into N steps to convert the continuous problem into a discontinuous problem over time domain. It is assumed that the node temperature is constant within each time interval Δt. The schematic of time discretization is shown in Figure 7(b). The curve of temperature Ti of node i versus heating time, denoted by short dash line, is replaced by the approximation temperature curve, denoted by solid line, after time discretization. The temperature of real point is equal to the temperature of node i in each time interval. Thus, the continuous problem over time domain has been converted into the discontinuous problem with N time steps.

sec.title: Mass transforming relationship
sec.p:
After discretizing the space and time domain, a volume element is chosen to analyze the volume ablation behavior. It is assumed that the density and volume fraction of silica fiber are constant in the present work. In addition, the mass transfer accompanying the gas flow between the considering volume element and adjacent volume elements can be described by the control volume model shown in Figure 8. Figure 8.
A control volume model of mass transforming relationship for silica-phenolic composites at high temperature.

The subscript 0 indicates the initial state, while the superscripts p, c, g and f indicate resin polymer phase, char phase, gas phase and fiber phase, respectively. The distribution of these phase components inside the material is assumed to be uniform after volume ablation and phase transition. The total volume of control volume is V0. According to the volume conservation principle of control volume, the following expression is satisfied. (1)Vp+Vc+Vg+V0 f=V0

The rate of decomposition of the solid material depends on temperature and activation energy and can be calculated by a modified Arrhenius equation29: (2)Jp=A0VpV0exp (-EaRT ) where A0 and Ea obtained by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) are the reaction rate constant and the activation energy, respectively. R is the gas constant. The curve of mass loss versus temperature calculated by the kinetic rate equation (2) is in close agreement with the TGA data as shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Comparison of kinetic rate equation (2) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment.

If the density of each phase component is constant during pyrolysis reaction, the mass transforming relationships are given by the following form. (3)ρ0 p∂Vp∂t=-Jp
(4)ρ0 c∂Vc∂t=Jp (1-Γp ) where Γp is the gasification coefficient of the matrix determined in TGA experiments. After Vp and Vc are solved by equations (3) and (4), they are substituted back into equation (1) to calculate the volume of gas phase. (5)Vg=V0-V0 f-Vp-Vc
The density of composite with volume ablation is described by the equation: (6)ρ=1V0 (ρ0 fV0 f+ρ0 pVp+ρ0 cVc )
It should be noted that the density of gas phase is ignored in equation (6).

If the gas flow in the material is governed by Darcy’s law, the mass flux of gas through the control volume is (7)mi g=-λimi gμiϕi gAΔδPi-Pi-1Δδ where subscript i indicates volume element i. μ, ϕg, A and λ are the gas viscosity in pore, volume fraction of gas in volume element, cross-sectional area of volume element and permeability of the material, respectively.
The gas pressure in pore is calculated using the equation of state in the following form: (8)PiAΔδϕi g=mi gM¯RTi

As shown in Figure 8, the mass conservation equation for gases of the volume element is given as: (9)mi g (t+Δt )-mi g (t )Δt=mi pg (t+Δt )-mi pg (t )Δt - [m·i g (t )-m·i-1 g (t ) ]A where mpg is the gas mass formed in the pyrolysis reaction. The left-hand side of equation (9) is the time rate of gas storage in the solid materials. It is equal to the sum of the time rate of gas generation and the rate of change of the gas mass flux through the volume element.

sec.title: Energy conservation equation
sec.p: For the one-dimensional heat and mass transfer problem, there are the following assumptions. (1) The decomposition gases are non-reactive and only flow through the thickness direction of materials. (2) The thermal equilibrium exists between the solid matrix and the decomposition gases.12 (3) The gas flow is steady, incompressible and irrotational and is governed by Darcy’s law.32–34 With these assumptions, the energy conservation is given by a modified Laplace’s equation. (10)ρCp∂T∂t=∂∂x (k∂T∂x )-∂∂x (m·ghg )-Q1ΔxA∂m∂t

The term on the left-hand side of equation (10) gives the change of internal energy of materials. Also, the three terms on the right relate respectively to heat conduction, convective heat transport and resin decomposition, which is endothermic.

Based on nodal thermal balance approach, equation (10) is transformed to equations (11), (19) and (21) in finite difference forms. The heat transfer process of volume element 1 at surface during volume ablation is illustrated in Figure 10(a). By this, the energy conservation equation of volume element 1 is written as (11)qwAΔt+Q1 pJ1 pAΔδ2Δt=qrAΔt+m1h1+qcond,1 +qconv,1-qconv,2
Figure 10.
Heat transfer process of volume element for silica-phenolic composites during volume ablation. (a) volume element 1, (b) volume element i and (c) volume element M + 1.

The terms on the left-hand side of equation (11) relate respectively to radiant heat flux and resin decomposition. Additionally, qw is the radiant heat flux applied perpendicular to the composite surface and is expressed by considering the heat effect of cold wall in the following form. (12)qw=qcw (1-hwhre ) where qcw, hw and hre are the cold wall heat flux, wall enthalpy and recovery enthalpy of gas at boundary layer, respectively. Q1 p of equation (11) is the heat of decomposition of volume element 1. It is noted that it is negative for endothermic reaction.

Furthermore, the thermal radiation of ablative materials is given by the first term on the right-hand side of equation (11), and is expressed as (13)qr=ɛσTw 4 where ɛ,σandTw are the emissivity, Stefan-Boltzmann constant and the temperature of ablative material at surface, respectively.

The second and third terms on the right hand side of equation (11) are the internal energy of materials and the energy of heat conduction between volume element 1 and 2, respectively. They can be expressed as follows: (14)m1h1=C1 ps (T1-T1 0 )ρAΔδ2
(15)qcond,1=T1-T2Δδk1AΔt where T1 0 is the temperature of node i at time t, while T1 is the temperature of node i at time t+Δt. Also, the fourth and fifth terms on the right hand are the energy of convection produced by the gas flow through volume element 1, which can be written as (16)qconv,1=C1 pg (T0-T1 )m1 gAΔt
(17)qconv,1=-C2 pg (T1-T2 )m2 gAΔt

In addition, C1 psandk1 in equations (14)–(16) are the specific heat and thermal conductivity of solid material, respectively C1 pg is the specific heat of decomposition gas. The relationship formulas of these terms and temperature proposed by Henderson12,13 are used in this paper. T0 is the ambient temperature in equation (16).

Thus, the expression of energy conservation equation of volume element 1 is rewritten as (18)qwAΔt+Q1 pJ1 pAΔδ2Δt=ɛσTw 4AΔt+C1 ps (T1-T1 0 )ρAΔδ2 +T1-T2Δδk1AΔt+C1 pg (T0-T1 )m·1 gAΔt +C2 pg(T1-T2)m·2 gAΔt

According to the heat transfer process of volume element i (i = 2, 3, … , M) during ablation shown in Figure 10(b), the energy conservation equation of volume element i is expressed as (19)qcond,i+Qi pJi pAΔδΔt=mihi+qcond,i+qconv,i+qconv,i+1
Similar to equation (18), equation (19) can be rewritten as: (20)Ti-1-TiΔδki-1AΔt+Qi pJi pAΔδΔt=Ci ps (Ti-Ti 0 )ρAΔδ +Ti-Ti+1ΔδkiAΔt -Ci pg (Ti-1-Ti )mi gAΔt +Ci+1 pg (Ti-Ti+1 )mi+1 gAΔt

It is assumed that there is no gas mass transfer process at back surface. According to the heat transfer process of volume element M + 1 at back surface during ablation as shown in Figure 10(c), the energy conservation equation of volume element M + 1 is given by the following expression. (21)qcond,M+QM+1 pJM+1 pAΔδ2Δt=mM+1hM+1+qconv,M+1
Similarly, equation (21) also can be rewritten as (22)TM-TM+1ΔδkMAΔt+CM+1 pg(TM-TM+1)m·M+1 gAΔt =CM+1 ps(TM+1-TM+1 0)ρAΔδ2 -QM+1 pJM+1 pAΔδ2Δt

sec.title: Thermal blockade effect
sec.p: As shown in morphology of silica-phenolic composite after volume ablation, the char layer near the heating surface is the most serious mass loss region, where the porosity and permeability are sufficiently large to cause the decomposition gases through the porous char structure into the gas boundary layer. Thus, the aerodynamic heating from the gas boundary layer may be blocked into ablative materials during this process.

The heat flux caused by thermal blockade effect, denoted by qψ, can be expressed by mass injection correlation ψ and the aerodynamic heat flux without mass injection qw (23)qψ= (1-ψ )qw where ψ is the ratio of heat transfer rate with mass injection to that without mass injection. By assuming the laminar flow of gas boundary layer, an approximate empirical relation of ψ proposed by Bethe and Adams30,35 is used to consider the thermal blockade effect, which is expressed as (24)ψ=1-0.62 (29Mj )0.26m·1 g (hreq0r ) where Mjandm·1 g are the molecular weight of injection gas and the mass flux of gas injected into boundary layer, respectively.
For considering the thermal blockade effect, the actual heat flux applied to the material is written as (25)qw'=qw-qψ

sec.title: Implementation of the moving boundary
sec.p: The thermal expansion during volume ablation causes the boundary movement in the thickness direction.36–38 Therefore, the moving boundary must be implemented in the calculation of temperature field to take into account the thermal expansion. The linear expansion of the composites is calculated by the following expression, which is similar to References [11–13]. (26)1Δδi (t )Δδi (t+Δt )-Δδi (t )Δt=ξmi pg (t )mi pg (t+Δt )-mi pg (t )Δt+ [ (1-ci )αvirg,i+ciαchar,i ]Ti (t+Δt )-Ti (t )Δt where αvirg,iandαchar,i are the coefficient of linear expansion of virgin and char materials of volume element i. ξ is the thermal decomposition expansion factor determined by experiment, which can evaluate the effect of pyrolysis reaction on the thermal expansion. c is the degree of decomposition, which takes the form: (27)c=m0-mm0-mfinal where mfinal is the final mass of materials when pyrolysis reaction completes.

The coordinate system is established for the material in the initial state and does not change during the thermal analysis in this study. Also, the node number and the amount of node do not change as same as the initial space discretization, whether the thermal expansion occurs or not. However, the node coordinate as a function of time is updated when the boundary moves. By updating the coordinate of each node at time t+Δt, the temperature of node i with new coordinate at time t, denoted by Ti' 0, is calculated using the Newton's interpolation method from the temperature results at time t, as shown in Figure 11. If the change in material thickness due to the thermal expansion is δ¯ during a time step, the thickness of volume element will become (28)Δδ'=(δ+δ¯)/M By taking the energy conservation equation (20) as an example, Δδ and Ti 0 of equation (20) is replaced with Δδ' and Ti' 0, respectively. Thus, equation (20) can be rewritten as (29)Ti-1-TiΔδ'ki-1AΔt+Qi pJi pAΔδ'Δt=Ci ps(Ti-Ti' 0)ρAΔδ' +Ti-Ti+1Δδ'kiAΔt -Ci pg(Ti-1-Ti)m·i gAΔt +Ci+1 pg(Ti-Ti+1)m·i+1 gAΔt
Figure 11.
Schematic of moving boundary due to thermal expansion.
Similarly, the energy conservation equations (18) and (22) can be revised further.

sec.title: Material properties
sec.p: The silica-phenolic composites are composed of silica fiber, phenolic resin and pores. The volume fractions of the three components are 38%, 51% and 11%, respectively. The kinetics parameters of thermodecomposition for silica-phenolic composites are obtained by TGA data. The variations of the thermal conductivity and specific heat of virgin and char components with temperature presented in References [39 and 40] are also considered in this paper. The thermal conductivity, specific heat, viscosity and molecular weight of the decomposition gases and thermal expansion coefficients of solid materials in References [12 and 13] are also applied in this paper. The permeability model in the present study is expressed as41 (30)log(λ)=(1-c)log(λvirg)+clog(λchar)

The basic properties of silica-phenolic composite materials are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Material properties of silica-phenolic composites
Properties Value Properties Value
ρ0 p(kg/m3) 1100 Cvirg ps(kJ/kgK) 1.09 + 1.09 × 10−3T [39,40]
ρ0 c(kg/m3) 2000 [29] Cchar ps(kJ/kgK) 0.88 + 1.02 × 10−3T [39,40]
ρ0 f(kg/m3) 2200 Cpg (kJ/kgK) 2.39 + 1.05 × 10−3T [12,13]
Ea (kJ/mol) 383.24 kvirg (kJ/msK) (8.0 + 2.76 × 10–3T) × 10–4 [39,40]
A0 (kg/m3s) 3.63e6 kchar (kJ/msK) (9.6 + 8.42 × 10−3T − 4.07 × 10–5T2) × 10−4 [39,40]
Γp 1.0 αvirg (1/K) 4.51 × 10−5 [12,13]
M¯(kg/mol) 0.018 αchar (1/K) −1.28 × 10−4 [12,13]
Qp (kJ/kg) −418.7 µ (kg/ms) 1.48 × 10−5 + 2.50 × 10−8T [12,13]
ɛ 0.65 λvirg (m2) 6.18 × 10−18 [41]
ξ (–) 0.88 [12,13] λchar (m2) 4.85 × 10−15 [41]

sec.title: Calculation process
sec.p:
An explicit method and implicit method can be formulated in finite difference methods. The implicit algorithm, where the spatial derivative is evaluated at the current time step, easily leads to a stable solution, and consequently it is used here. The energy conservation equation of M + 1 volume elements can constitute a typical tri-diagonal system of algebraic equations for temperature, which are solved using chase-after method. While dealing with moving boundary, if Ti 0 is given, Ti' 0 is solved using Newton backward interpolation. It should be pointed out that since the mass flux of gases, pore pressure and gas mass of control volume are coupled, it is necessary to be solved by using Newton iteration method and combining equations (7)--(9) in order to achieve convergence. Moreover, adjacent nodal values of the transport properties, such as viscosity coefficient, permeability and thermal conductivity, are used to calculate the harmonic mean of these properties at the control volume interfaces. These interface properties are then used in the solution of the governing equations. The flow chart of detailed solving process is shown in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Flow chart of solving process for proposed model.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Using the material properties presented in Table 1 and the mathematical model developed in Section 4, the one-dimensional thermal response of silica-phenolic composite corresponding to the experimental specimens 1 and 2 is calculated. The time-dependent temperature at different depths of silica-phenolic materials under heat flux loading provided in Figure 5 are calculated and compared to the values measured by radiant heating experiment as shown in Figure 13. The experimental temperatures for initial depths of 2.5, 8.5 and 13.5 mm are presented as data points. Also, the predicted temperatures at the same spatial locations are presented. It can be found that the calculated results of two heat flux conditions are in good agreement with the experimental values. Additionally, as can be seen, the increase of temperature is very slow in the initial stage due to the low heat flux applied to specimen 1. When the heat flux reaches a stable value of 250 kW/m2, the temperature increases rapidly at depth of 2.5 mm, while increases slowly at depths of 8.5 mm and 13.5 mm. This should be attributed to the low thermal conductivity and excellent heat resistance for the composite. The temperature of specimen 1 at the back surface does not change at heating time 34 s. Moreover, for specimen 2, there is an inflection point of the temperature curve at depth of 2.5 mm at 65 s, because the heat flux of 100 kW/m2 at 60 s increases quickly to 300 kW/m2 at 62 s. In particular, the inflection point of temperature appears at 65 s while heat flux changes into 300 kW/m2 at 62 s. This is possible because the long-time heat transfer delay the change of temperature. Figure 13.
Experimental and calculated time-dependent temperature at different depths (from heating surface 2.5 mm, 8.0 mm, and 13.5 mm) under heat flux loading shown in Figure 5. (a) specimen 1 and (b) specimen 2.

Figure 14 is the variation curves of volume fraction of each phase of the volume element at external surface with temperature during the volume ablation. The resin polymer phase can transfer into char phase and gas phase when thermal decomposition of material occurs. Thus, during the pyrolysis reactions process, the volume fraction of polymer phase decreases, while the volume fraction of char phase and gas phase increases. However, the sum of three volume fraction terms of the three phases remains a constant at any time during the volume ablation process. At the final stage, only char and pores of the volume element at external surface exist because of the complete carbonization of the resin polymer. In addition, the slope of volume fraction of each phase has an inflection point at 580℃, which can be attributed to the sharp increase in the external heat flux. According to the work reported by Dimitrienko29 and Liang,42 the temperature boundary condition is given, which increases with a constant heating rate. Then, the volume fraction of each phase with different heating rates versus temperature is illustrated in Figure 15. Comparison of Figures 14 and 15 reveals that the variation curves in Figure 14 are close to the curves in Figure 15 corresponding to the heating rate 2℃/s. Therefore, the heat flux of specimen 2 is similar to the condition of heating rate 2℃/s. Figure 14.
Variation of volume fraction of each phase component of the volume element at external surface versus temperature under heat flux loading shown in Figure 5(b).
Figure 15.
Variation of volume fraction of each phase component of composites versus temperature with different heating rates during volume ablation.
Figure 16.
Experimental and calculated temperature distribution of the material in the thickness direction under two heat flux conditions shown in Figure 5.
Figure 17.
Temperature distribution of the material in the thickness direction under constant heat flux of 200 kW/m2 with and without moving boundary.

Figure 16 illustrates the through-thickness temperature distribution of materials with two heat flux conditions shown in Figure 5. It is observed that the temperature gradient in the material is large, and the thermal expansion phenomenon is not obvious due to the short heating time. In order to obtain the evident thermal expansion phenomenon, the temperature distribution of materials under a constant heat flux of 200 kW/m2 with heating time of 100 s and 200 s are calculated and plotted in Figure 17. It can be seen from the temperature curves that the thickness of materials increases from an initial value of 15 mm to approximately 15.8 mm at 200 s. The effect of moving boundary on temperature is evident. The difference of predicted temperature is 50℃ between considering moving boundary and without.

The pore pressure distributions of materials under constant heat flux of 200 kW/m2 with heating time of 100 s and 200 s are plotted in Figure 18. It is important to point out that the pore pressure has a local peak during the volume ablation and exhibits a parabola tendency in the thickness direction of materials. Furthermore, the peak moves towards the back surface of materials with heating time. Meanwhile, both curves have a step at the initial curved regions. It reveals that the gases cannot escape to the boundary layer completely within the calculated time. It also can be found that the pore ​​pressure increases with heating time from a maximum of approximately 3.85 MPa at 100 s to 6.36 MPa at 200 s. This is possible because the heat-affected zone penetrates further into the virgin solid with the heating time, which may make the decomposition gas stored in the materials difficultly diffuse to the surface of the material. Figure 19 shows the variation of degree of decomposition with the thickness of the composites. The value 1 of degree of decomposition indicates the pyrolysis reaction has completed, while the value 0 of degree of decomposition indicates that the pyrolysis reaction has not happened. It is also revealed in comparison of Figures 18 and 19 that the peak pore pressure does not correspond to the intensive thermal decomposition but appears just after the onset of the pyrolysis reaction. The reason is that the porosity is still quite small at this early stage of pyrolysis reaction. Thus, the accumulation of the decomposition gas is more likely to cause a higher pore pressure. Figure 18.
Pore pressure distribution of the material in the thickness direction under constant heat flux of 200 kW/m2 with heating time of 100 s and 200 s.
Figure 19.
Variation of degree of decomposition with the thickness of the composites under constant heat flux of 200 kW/m2 with heating time of 100 s and 200 s.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The one-dimensional finite difference formulas were established to predict the transient thermal response of silica-phenolic thermoprotective composites under high temperature. The volume ablation process and the associated heat-mass transfer process were studied in the formulation of the developed model. A solar radiation heating experiment platform, which can provide a high radiant heat flux in a short time, was carried out to evaluate the accuracy of the thermal response model.

Comparing the calculated temperature with the experimental values, the proposed model can satisfactorily predict the thermal response of the silica-phenolic composite undergoing volume ablation. Additionally, it is observed that the temperature gradient is large in the material. The thermal expansion phenomenon of materials is evident in the volume ablation process with heating time of 200 s. The thermal expansion can significantly affect the temperature results, which are considered in the thermal response model by implementing the moving boundary. The pore pressure has a local peak during the volume ablation, and the peak moves towards the back surface of the material with heating time.
